speaker: Neil
text: Welcome to 6 Minute English, the programme where we bring you an interesting topic and six useful words or phrases. I'm Neil.

speaker: Dan
text: And I'm Dan. Today we're talking about one of the last mysteries of science. No, not if the universe will keep expanding forever, but this: how do cats and dogs find their way home over long distances?

speaker: Neil
text: We hear incredible stories of lost pets travelling tens and even hundreds of miles home – but scientists struggle to explain how they do it.

speaker: a cat persona dog person
text: We'll hear the view of one scientist today. But before that – I have to ask an important question: Neil, are you a cat person or a dog person?

speaker: a cat person
text: Oh, that's easy – I'm a cat person, for sure. Dogs are just a… well, they are hard work, aren't they?

speaker: a cat personA coffee person
text: If you say you are 'a cat person' it means you prefer cats. 'A coffee person' prefers coffee. A 'something' person likes or prefers that thing, often over another thing.

speaker: a cat person
text: Back to the topic, I'm a cat person. But can you answer this, Dan? Recently, a cat called Omar made headlines for being, possibly, the world's longest cat. How long is Omar? Is it…

speaker: a cat person
text: a) 120 cm

speaker: a cat person
text: b) 80 cm

speaker: a cat person
text: Or c) 180 cm

speaker: Dan
text: I'm gonna say c) 180 cm.

speaker: scratching their heads
text: Now, from long cats to long-distance cats. Scientists were scratching their heads a couple of years ago when a lost cat called Holly travelled 200 miles to get home. How did it do it?

speaker: scratch your head
text: We say you 'scratch your head' when you are confused about something. There are a few theories about how cats and dogs navigate – but we don't yet have the full answer.

speaker: landmarkslandmark
text: Well, both cats and dogs have an extremely powerful sense of smell, of course. Smells are like signposts – they let you know where you are. Visual landmarks also play a role, just as they do with humans. A landmark is something very easily recognised – a big building or mountain for example.

speaker: magnetsmagnetic
text: And what about this one: magnets are pieces of metal which attract certain other kinds of metal - for example, iron or steel. The Earth itself has a magnetic force.

speaker: Neil
text: Birds use it to help them navigate over thousands of miles – it tells them where north is. It's thought they have some iron in their beaks.

speaker: Dan
text: But some scientists think mammals also have this capability.

speaker: landmarksmagnetic
text: So we have a few ideas – smell, landmarks, magnetic forces – but can we explain how one kitty travelled over 200 miles by itself back to its home?

speaker: Dan
text: Let's hear from cat and dog expert Dr John Bradshaw. How do cats build up the maps in their heads?

speaker: territorysystematicterritory
text: What they do when they are in a new territory is explore it in a very systematic way. So they will go out in ever-increasing circles, they'll literally construct a mental map in their heads. And so a cat that's lost its territory probably does the same thing. They'll rely on the idea that if they go out in ever-increasing circles or rectangles then eventually they'll either come across the territory or they'll come across a smell carried on the wind of the territory that they used to live in and then be able to go home.

speaker: systematicsystem
text: Cats have a systematic approach – which means they use a system. Which is: first they walk around their area in a small circle, then a bigger one and then a bigger one – until they have a strong mental map of the place.

speaker: territoryterritorialterritory
text: Yes – a mental map is a map in your head – stored in your memory. And the area cats explore – their home area - is called their territory. Cats are territorial – which means their territory is very important to them.

speaker: landmark
text: Having a map is great, but what happens when a cat gets lost? Dr Bradshaw says that again, it moves around in bigger and bigger circles, until it finds a clue – which is a landmark or a smell – that tells it where it is. Well, that's the theory. Though Dr Bradshaw says we really still don't have enough data – that's enough information about this.

speaker: Neil
text: When there is a scientific breakthrough - we'll bring it to you in 6 Minute English, I hope. For now, let's content ourselves with Omar, possibly, the world's longest cat. How long, Dan?

speaker: Dan
text: I said 180 cm.

speaker: Neil
text: Omar measures 120 cm – that's over two thirds of my height – and weighs a heavy 14 kg.

speaker: Dan
text: Well, one thing, Neil, if Omar ever got lost, he'd be found in no time.

speaker: landmarka cat personan evening person
text: He's a landmark in himself! Which reminds me – let's run through today's words again. If you're a cat person, you prefer cats. If you're an evening person – you prefer evenings.

speaker: Dan
text: I've always thought you were a kind person, Neil.

speaker: Neil
text: Nice of you to say, but we only use the phrase with nouns, not adjectives!

speaker: scratching their heads
text: Indeed. We don't want the listeners to be scratching their heads.

speaker: landmarklandmarks
text: No, we can't confuse them! So let's explain the next one clearly – a landmark is something easily recognisable that lets you know where you are. The bridges in London are landmarks.

speaker: magnetsmagnet territory
text: And can we say the parks are magnets in summer? A magnet is a piece of metal that attracts iron and steel – but we can also use the word more widely to describe things that attract other things. Two more words: territory is a noun – the area of land that an animal considers to be its own.

speaker: territorial
text: Animals who feel this strongly are described as territorial. Humans can be too – about land or subjects they feel they own or control.
